Chicken Stir-Fry

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the ultimate guide for a quick and delicious Chicken Stir-Fry that brings the vibrant flavors of the Asian kitchen right to your home! In just 30 minutes, you can whip up a satisfying meal that's not only packed with protein but also loaded with colorful vegetables like bell peppers and broccoli. This chicken stir-fry recipe is perfect for busy weeknights when you need a nutritious dinner on the table fast. With tender chicken breast, a savory soy sauce glaze, and a hint of garlic and ginger, every bite is a burst of flavor that your family will love. Plus, it's customizable to your taste; feel free to add your favorite veggies or adjust the seasonings! Dive into this easy-to-follow recipe and discover how simple it is to create a restaurant-quality dish in your own kitchen. Let's get cooking!

Ingredients

chicken breast

Choose skinless, boneless chicken breasts for a lean option. If you're short on time, pre-cut chicken strips or use chicken thighs for added flavor and moisture. Marinating the chicken in soy sauce for 30 minutes can enhance its flavor and tenderness.

bell peppers

Use a mix of colors (red, yellow, green) for a visually appealing dish and a variety of flavors. If bell peppers are unavailable, you can substitute with other crunchy vegetables like snap peas or carrots.

broccoli florets

Fresh broccoli is best, but frozen florets can work in a pinch. To enhance the broccoli's flavor, you can blanch it briefly before adding it to the stir-fry. This helps maintain its bright color and crisp texture.

soy sauce

Use low-sodium soy sauce if you're watching your sodium intake. For a gluten-free option, look for tamari or coconut aminos. Adding a splash of rice vinegar can brighten the flavors.

garlic

Fresh garlic provides the best flavor, but if you don't have it, garlic powder is a decent substitute (1/8 teaspoon for each clove). To enhance its flavor, sauté the garlic briefly before adding the other ingredients.

ginger

Fresh ginger adds a zesty kick. If unavailable, ground ginger can be used as a substitute (1/4 teaspoon for 1 teaspoon fresh). Grating the ginger will release more flavor than chopping.

olive oil

While olive oil is a healthy option, you can also use other oils with higher smoke points like canola or peanut oil for stir-frying. Adding a drop of sesame oil at the end can impart a warm, nutty flavor.

cornstarch

Cornstarch is used to thicken sauces. If you don't have it, arrowroot powder or tapioca starch can be used as substitutes. Mix cornstarch with cold water to avoid clumping before adding to the sauce.

water

Water is used to adjust the sauce consistency. You can replace it with chicken broth for additional flavor. If you want a thicker sauce, reduce the amount of water.

sesame seeds

Toasting sesame seeds before adding them as a garnish will enhance their nutty flavor. If you don't have sesame seeds, chopped nuts like cashews or peanuts can provide a similar crunch.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Ingredients

    Slice the chicken breast into thin strips. This ensures that the chicken cooks quickly and evenly.

  • Step 2: Chop the Vegetables

    Chop the bell peppers and broccoli into bite-sized pieces. This makes them easier to eat and helps them cook faster.

  • Step 3: Make the Sauce

    In a bowl, mix soy sauce, minced garlic, grated ginger, cornstarch, and water to create a smooth sauce. The cornstarch helps to thicken the sauce later.

  • Step 4: Heat the Oil

    Heat olive oil in a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat. Make sure the oil is hot enough before adding the chicken to achieve a nice sear.

  • Step 5: Cook the Chicken

    Add the chicken strips to the skillet and stir-fry until they are golden brown and cooked through, which takes about 5-7 minutes. Stir frequently to prevent sticking.

  • Step 6: Add Vegetables

    Add the chopped bell peppers and broccoli to the skillet and stir-fry for another 3-4 minutes until the vegetables are tender-crisp, retaining some crunch.

  • Step 7: Combine and Thicken Sauce

    Pour the sauce over the chicken and vegetables, stir well, and cook for an additional 2 minutes until the sauce thickens. Stir continuously to coat everything evenly.

  • Step 8: Serve

    Serve hot, garnished with sesame seeds if desired. This adds a nice crunch and visual appeal to your dish.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I safely handle raw chicken?

Always wash your hands before and after handling raw chicken. Use separate cutting boards for raw meat and vegetables to avoid cross-contamination.

What is the best way to slice chicken breast?

To slice chicken breast more easily, freeze it for about 30 minutes before slicing. This firms it up and allows for cleaner cuts. Always slice against the grain for tenderness.

How do I know when chicken is cooked through?

The internal temperature of cooked chicken should reach 165°F (75°C). You can use a meat thermometer to check or cut into the thickest part to ensure there is no pink meat.

What does 'stir-fry' mean?

Stir-frying is a quick cooking method that involves frying small pieces of food in a small amount of hot oil while stirring continuously. It helps to preserve the texture and color of the ingredients.

How can I chop vegetables quickly and safely?

To chop vegetables quickly, use a sharp knife and keep your fingers curled under your knuckles for safety. Practice the 'claw grip' with your non-cutting hand to guide the vegetable while slicing.

What can I substitute for soy sauce?

If you need a soy sauce substitute, you can use tamari (for gluten-free), coconut aminos, or a mixture of vinegar and salt. Adjust to taste.

How do I make vegetables tender-crisp?

To achieve tender-crisp vegetables, stir-fry them for about 3-4 minutes. They should be bright in color and still have some crunch. Avoid overcooking.

What should I do if I burn the chicken?

If your chicken starts to burn, immediately reduce the heat and add a splash of water or broth to deglaze the pan, scraping up the burnt bits. This can add flavor and prevent further burning.

Is it necessary to use cornstarch in the sauce?

Cornstarch is used to thicken sauces. If you prefer not to use it, you can skip it, but your sauce will be thinner. Alternatively, you can use flour or arrowroot powder as a thickening agent.

What can I do with leftovers?

Leftovers can be stored in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days. You can also reheat them in the microwave or make a wrap or salad with the chicken stir-fry.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For gluten-free options, substitute soy sauce with tamari or a gluten-free soy sauce alternative. To cater to those preferring plant-based meals, replace chicken with tofu or tempeh, and ensure the sauce is made with gluten-free ingredients. This dish can also be made low-carb by serving it over cauliflower rice.

Pairings

A great pairing for Chicken Stir-Fry includes jasmine rice or brown rice to soak up the flavorful sauce. For a protein boost, consider serving it alongside grilled shrimp or a side of miso soup. As for beverages, a light white wine like Pinot Grigio or a refreshing iced green tea can complement the dish beautifully, enhancing the flavors without overpowering them.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Chicken Stir-Fry hot, directly from the skillet or wok to the table for a casual and inviting presentation. For an elegant touch, use a large white platter to display the stir-fry, and garnish with fresh cilantro or sliced green onions. Providing chopsticks alongside forks can add an authentic Asian dining experience.

#

Chicken Stir-Fry

25 min
$12.5
320 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

Soy

Dietary Tags:

Gluten-FreeHigh-Protein

Cuisine:

AsianAmerican

Course:

Main CourseDinner

Tags:

QuickHealthyFamily Meal

Description

A quick and flavorful dish combining tender chicken with fresh vegetables, tossed in a savory sauce.

Ingredients

  • chicken breast: 1 pound
  • bell peppers: 2 (any color)
  • broccoli florets: 1 cup
  • soy sauce: 3 tablespoons
  • garlic: 2 cloves
  • ginger: 1 teaspoon
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • cornstarch: 1 tablespoon
  • water: 1/4 cup
  • sesame seeds: 1 tablespoon (optional)

Date Created:

11/18/2024
